texts.definition: A route in a game world that players need to traverse to get to certain locations.
markups: <style="Definition">A route in a game world that players need to traverse to get to certain locations.</style>

Games with game worlds typically have several areas where interesting gameplay can occur. Although interesting gameplay can occur in them, <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> are the areas in-between the areas explicitly designed to provide interesting gameplay (or narration).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Snakes%20&%20Ladders">Snakes & Ladders</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Afrikan%20T%C3%A4hti">Afrikan TÃ¤hti</link></style> are examples of old <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> where only some of the location spaces cause gameplay events to occur, making the others <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> between these. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Wizard's%20Apprentice">Wizard's Apprentice</link></style> is an experimental <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-Augmented%20Board%20Games">Computer-Augmented Board Game</link></style> with the same design structure.

Both "old-school" <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> contain <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> in the form of corridors. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%20series">Half-Life series</link></style> have these also but also provide a section in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%202">Half-Life 2</link></style> where one uses a car to move over longer distances.

The basic purpose of <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> is to require <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> between two points in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. Alternatives to using <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> include <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>. One way of creating <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> is "cutting" or "spanning" through otherwise impassable game world materials, and here <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style> is a special case which requires or strongly promotes the use of <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>. Another way it to limit <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> possibilities through <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> so that the remaining routes are the only <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style>. A third option is simply to use <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cut%20Scenes">Cut Scenes</link></style>.

As a pattern relating to connecting locations together, it has relations to many such patterns relating to connections. <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> can be used to only make the <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> accessible at some point during gameplay while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style> limits access to one direction. <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style> makes travelling in one direction optional while <style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style> makes it a requirement.

Unlike <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> since the pattern make <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> possible between places in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> that should or could be diegetically possible. <style="Link"><link="illusion-open-space">Illusion of Open Space</link></style> can be necessary to include in <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> when striving for <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> if the diegesis implies that one would be able to perceive more of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> from the <style="CurrentLink">Transport Route</style> than the route itself.

<style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> is not a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style> in itself but narration can be provided in <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> to make them more interesting. The most natural way to do this is through <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> since it is an environment, and examples of patterns that can be used for this reason (or to just make the routes more varied) include <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> give rise to basic <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals of moving from one end of it to the other. They can create <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> if opposing exists or the transport capacity is limited, and <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style> if several different <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> between the same start and end area exists. <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> can be necessary when players have several <style="CurrentLink">Transport Routes</style> to choose from and <style="Link"><link="lull-periods">Lull Periods</link></style> can occur if they are sufficiently long and do not require much attention from players.

<style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="illusion-open-space">Illusion of Open Space</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style>
